bibl.title: Letter from Frederick V. Coville to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 30, 1929

div1.p: Coville offers gardening advice to Emilie.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick V. Coville to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 30, 1929
div1.opener:
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
BUREAU OF PLANT INDUSTRY
WASHINGTON August 30, 1929.
BOTANY
Mrs. Walter Reed,
Blue Ridge Summit,
Pennsylvania.
Dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
Replying to your letter of August 28 I suggest that in place of kerosene
you use in the hollowed-out stump a very heavy application of ordinary salt.
Kerosene will injure the living wood of the stump, but its effects will dis-
appear as the kerosene evaporates. Used oil from an automobile engine will
not evaporate and would cause much more injury to the stump than kerosene, but
it also would keep the soil in bad condition for many years.

In addition to any applications of salt or other killing material, it is
important that no sprouts be allowed to grow from the stump or from any of the
roots of the tree. As fast as sprouts appear they should be broken off promptly.
This alone in the end would starve the roots until they die, as they cannot live
indefinitely without the starch that is manufactured in the leaves.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Frederick V. Coville
Botanist. FVC:CBP.
